issue.title: NeRFStudio + Volinga: Wrong ckpt format with NeRFStudio latest commit.
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I have just updated NeRFStudio to the latest commit, and since then it seems that the ckpt (trained using ns-train volinga...) do not work with the Volinga convertor. After a successful upload I get the error code 607 and message "Wrong ckpt format"

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Train a NeRF using `ns-train volinga...`
2. Upload the generated ckpt on Volinga's website
3. After few second that processing has started, it fails

**Additional context**
Even if there is a thread on Volinga's Discord server about this, I thought it could be useful to open an issue here too. It seems that the ckpt structure has changed.

comment.body:
@machenmusik ,
thank you for your suggestion.
I have tried to build environment that satisfy :
- cuda-toolkit, cuda-runtime, cuda-visual-studio integration,  and nvidia graphics driver by cuda_11.8.0_522.06_windows.exe
  The installation was checked by executing `nvcc` and `nvidia-smi`. They are all version 11.8.
- visual c++
  This was checked by `cl` command.
- python version of 3.10.13


After building the environment, I re-tried the installation:
```
#install pip packages
python -m pip install --upgrade pip
python -m pip install torch==2.0.1+cu118 torchvision==0.15.2+cu118 torchaudio==2.0.2 --extra-index-url https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cu118
#tiny-cuda installation
git clone https://github.com/NVlabs/tiny-cuda-nn.git
cd tiny-cuda-nn
git submodule update --init --recursive
python -m pip install ./bindings/torch
```

But `python -m pip install ./bindings/torch` failed...

The error message is as follows:
```
Processing c:\users\UserName\tiny-cuda-nn\bindings\torch
  Installing build dependencies ... done
  Getting requirements to build wheel ... error
  error: subprocess-exited-with-error

  × Getting requirements to build wheel did not run successfully.
  │ exit code: 1
  ╰─> [18 lines of output]
      <string>:5: DeprecationWarning: pkg_resources is deprecated as an API. See https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/latest/pkg_resources.html
      Traceback (most recent call last):
        File "C:\Users\UserName\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python310\lib\site-packages\pip\_vendor\pyproject_hooks\_in_process\_in_process.py", line 353, in <module>
          main()
        File "C:\Users\UserName\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python310\lib\site-packages\pip\_vendor\pyproject_hooks\_in_p          json_out['return_val'] = hook(**hook_input['kwargs'])
        File "C:\Users\UserName\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python310\lib\site-packages\pip\_vendor\pyproject_hooks\_in_process\_in_process.py", line 118, in get_requires_for_build_wheel
          return hook(config_settings)
        File "C:\Users\UserName\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-build-env-0c0t_z5q\overlay\Lib\site-packages\setuptools\build_meta.py", line 355, in get_requires_for_build_wheel
          return self._get_build_requires(config_settings, requirements=['wheel'])
        File "C:\Users\UserName\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-build-env-0c0t_z5q\overlay\Lib\site-packages\setuptools\build_meta.py", line 325, in _get_build_requires
          self.run_setup()
        File "C:\Users\UserName\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-build-env-0c0t_z5q\overlay\Lib\site-packages\setuptools\build_meta.py", line 507, in run_setup
          super(_BuildMetaLegacyBackend, self).run_setup(setup_script=setup_script)
        File "C:\Users\UserName\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-build-env-0c0t_z5q\overlay\Lib\site-packages\setuptools\build_meta.py", line 341, in run_setup
          exec(code, locals())
        File "<string>", line 9, in <module>
      ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'torch'
      [end of output]

  note: This error originates from a subprocess, and is likely not a problem with pip.
error: subprocess-exited-with-error

× Getting requirements to build wheel did not run successfully.
│ exit code: 1
╰─> See above for output.

note: This error originates from a subprocess, and is likely not a problem with pip.
```
That says "ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'torch'".
Torch installation I think was successful because I entered python interpreter mode and `import torch` was successful.

issue.title: Download links (nerfstudio-dataset) are down
issue.body:
Tried to re-download the nerfstudio-dataset and the links are down for some capture names (scenes). Say by running:

ns-download-data nerfstudio --capture-name all;

Resolving data.nerf.studio (data.nerf.studio)... 34.102.68.79                                                                                 
Connecting to data.nerf.studio (data.nerf.studio)|34.102.68.79|:443... connected.                                                             
HTTP request sent, awaiting response... 404 File not found                                                                                    
2023-10-27 08:21:23 ERROR 404: File not found.

The links redirect to this:
https://data.nerf.studio/nerfstudio/{CAPTURE_NAME}.zip

But only these are the capture names that cannot be found: Egypt,person,kitchen,plane,dozer,floating-tree,aspen,stump,sculpture,Giannini-Hall

The rest of capture names downloaded successfully.

issue.title: NeRFStudio + Volinga: Wrong ckpt format with NeRFStudio latest commit.
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I have just updated NeRFStudio to the latest commit, and since then it seems that the ckpt (trained using ns-train volinga...) do not work with the Volinga convertor. After a successful upload I get the error code 607 and message "Wrong ckpt format"

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Train a NeRF using `ns-train volinga...`
2. Upload the generated ckpt on Volinga's website
3. After few second that processing has started, it fails

**Additional context**
Even if there is a thread on Volinga's Discord server about this, I thought it could be useful to open an issue here too. It seems that the ckpt structure has changed.

comment.body: (@AFMagnon do you have CUDA libraries and  Visual Studio installed?  CUDA version 11.8 is known to work well, and IIRC community versions of VS may suffice... not sure whether just windows-build-tools does)

(@Frivas97 if it's not already there, you may want to add the tiny-cuda-nn requirement to docs and maybe even implementation of your method, as it differels from others...)

issue.title: Gaussian splatting
issue.body:
A home-grown re-implementation of splatting! It uses [gsplat](https://github.com/nerfstudio-project/gsplat) as the rasterization backend, which has some nice features like rendering higher dimensional features and more pythonic bindings exposed to the user. Here's a video of a partially trained model in the viewer, and some completed video renders:


https://github.com/nerfstudio-project/nerfstudio/assets/15806475/965c4d6c-cbc6-455b-b588-e29bfe61f9f1

https://github.com/nerfstudio-project/nerfstudio/assets/15806475/e23a7c17-ffce-4125-af23-32cf2eb1ed0c

https://github.com/nerfstudio-project/nerfstudio/assets/15806475/b25cf6d2-7654-493f-9285-b71b1b4a533c





Implementation-wise, there are still some things to be done:
- unify the datamanager pipeline, currently there is a full_images_datamanager which is disjoint from the
- to support rasterization, we had to overload get_outputs to take in a Camera or Raybundle. This is a bit hacky, ideally we would have a cleaner way of supporting this behavior, maybe a subclass of Model called RasterizationModel or something.
- Some parts of the pipeline like exporting point-clouds won't fully work (cropping not implemented yet), and it's unclear how well the depth will work for pointclouds
- Currently cropping is implemented by calling a set_crop function. This works well, but it's a bit divergent from the RayBundle strategy of cropping which crops the near and far plans for each ray before passing it into the model. this could make code messy in rendering/export pipelines since we need to case on whether the model is a raybundle or rasterization model

There's lots of exciting things which _could_ be done too, like floater removal via the viewer, exporting as PLY, or exporting cropped scenes to get object-centric models.

comment.body: This branch is getting to be pretty substantial... is there a schedule/timetable planned to consider merging?

commits.message:
Expose camera frustums size and occlusions to CLI (#2556)

CLI expose for camera frustums

pull_request.title: Expose camera frustums size and occlusions to CLI
pull_request.body: I added two parameters to the Viewer config. Now we can change the size of the training & eval camera frustums, and we can enable/disable rendering the scene with depth compositing. This is useful for (1) when the scene is small and frustums are too tiny or (2) when there are floaters or artifacts in the way and you still want to see the camera frustums. **Default, trained for a little bit.** ```bash ns-train nerfacto --data data/nerfstudio/plane --vis viewer_beta ``` **Modifying the camera frustum scale from the default 0.1 to 1.0 (10x) and turning off depth compositing.** ```bash ns-train nerfacto --data data/nerfstudio/plane --vis viewer_beta --viewer.camera_frustum_scale 1.0 --viewer.default_composite_depth False ```

repo.name: nerfstudio
repo.description: A collaboration friendly studio for NeRFs

commits.message:
Missing a space in base_datamanager.py (#2546)

Update base_datamanager.py

Fix pixel-perfect-sfm installation in Dockerfile (#2549)

fix: Fix pixel-perfect-sfm installation in Dockerfile

static imgs never rendered in multiclient (#2551)

* fix jittering in markdown in viewer beta

* Revert "fix jittering in markdown in viewer beta"

This reverts commit 70ade42e46f3dcf0e89e4efc445650f6d6525673.

* static rendering never triggered

Move only per-chunk data to the GPU to support rendering large images (#2481)

* Move only per-chunk data to the GPU to support large images

* make type checking happy

* Use isinstance check

torch.is_tensor() doesn't have a TypeGuard annotation

---------

Co-authored-by: Brent Yi <yibrenth@gmail.com>

make refine intrinsics during ns-process-data optional (#2550)

ns-process-data will still refine intrinsics by default for compatibility.

Specify --no-refine-intrinsics to turn off.

Few viewer changes (#2553)

* Viewer changes for render panel for fps and resolution

Small changes for the new viewer including changing the FPS slider to a text entry and fixing the incorrect resolution text box description.

* Check if render_time is nonzero in render state machine

Added a check if render_time is non zero in the render_state_machine file in the new viewer due to a divide by zero error occasionally causing the viewer to stop running. I noticed this usually happened when using nerfacto-huge.

ns-process-data images fix: multinerf uses equals sign (#2558)

multinerf uses equals sign

Add gradient scaling option to more methods (#2555)

add gradient scaling to instant-ngp, mipnerf, tensorf, vanilla-nerf

Add gradient scaling option to more methods (#2555)

add gradient scaling to instant-ngp, mipnerf, tensorf, vanilla-nerf

pull_request.title: Add gradient scaling option to more methods
pull_request.body: Here is a proposal to add gradient scaling as an option to other methods like instant-ngp, mipnerf, tensorf, vanilla-nerf.  It is disabled by default so it won't change existing behaviour. The code was copied from the nerfacto method.

issue.title: about depth loss increasing.
issue.body:
Hi,
When I add the use the `depth-nerfacto`,  the depth loss and intervel loss increased.\
The train script is below.
````
export CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES=0
ns-train depth-nerfacto  --viewer.websocket-port=7009 \
                --machine.num-gpus 1 \
                --experiment-name kitti_00_200_depth \
                --data data/kitti/kitti_00_200_depth \
                --vis tensorboard 
````
The detailed log is below.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14838781/219670436-3a04165c-3c86-4b55-93e0-bc9f473c5235.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14838781/219672319-0c1ef6da-39bc-4de7-9cfc-e68f511131a9.png)
The predicted depth map
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14838781/219672553-29453f0c-810a-4bb9-9e6f-b34fba39ce05.png)
The render image
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14838781/219672835-c8aa3a13-f267-4e7b-85d5-b9c2fd520a5d.png)

comment.body: @ethanweber I studied your suggestion of training nerf model without depth supervision in more detail -- I find the predicted depth without any supervision is at very different scale than my "ground-truth" which might point to some convention / normalization differences. I am attaching below the precise numbers I see: you will notice that the predicted depth (after scaling back to original depth space) is very different than ground truth. The depths are z-depths i.e. distance from camera plane and I am using the default is_euclidean_depth: False Any help would be greatly appreciated! Thank you!

issue.title: NeRFStudio + Volinga: Wrong ckpt format with NeRFStudio latest commit.
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I have just updated NeRFStudio to the latest commit, and since then it seems that the ckpt (trained using ns-train volinga...) do not work with the Volinga convertor. After a successful upload I get the error code 607 and message "Wrong ckpt format"

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Train a NeRF using `ns-train volinga...`
2. Upload the generated ckpt on Volinga's website
3. After few second that processing has started, it fails

**Additional context**
Even if there is a thread on Volinga's Discord server about this, I thought it could be useful to open an issue here too. It seems that the ckpt structure has changed.

comment.body: If tiny cuda is not available, NeRFStudio will use vanilla Pytorch to train the model. The problem is that the way in which the model is stored in the ckpt varies depending if you use tiny cuda or not. At this moment, we only support the tiny cuda "format" on Volinga exporter. This is probably the reason for the failure.

Thank you for your comment, Frivas97.
Thats right, I did not install tiny-cuda-nn.
After installing `ninja`, I failed installing tiny-cuda-nn with following error message:
```
 Built on Wed_Sep_21_10:41:10_Pacific_Daylight_Time_2022
      Cuda compilation tools, release 11.8, V11.8.89
      Build cuda_11.8.r11.8/compiler.31833905_0
      Detected CUDA version 11.8
      Targeting C++ standard 17
      running bdist_wheel
      D:\anaconda3\envs\nerfstudio_py310\lib\site-packages\torch\utils\cpp_extension.py:476: UserWarning: Attempted to use ninja as the BuildExtension backend but we could not find ninja.. Falling back to using the slow distutils backend.
        warnings.warn(msg.format('we could not find ninja.'))
```
Without this package, I succeeded to implement `ns-train nerfacto --data data/nerfstudio/poster`.
So, I thought this is not necessary...
